author: Albuquerque Journal Editorial Board
title: Editorial: Understaffed NM prisons are a powder keg concern
text:
When is the last time you put in a 72-hour workweek on any kind of job, much less a dangerous one? Probably never, if you are an average 40-hour-a-week worker.
Unfortunately, due to difficulty in recruiting and retaining prison officers, New Mexico’s state-run prisons are seriously understaffed, and some officers are working those crushing workweeks.
As Sgt. Robert Darnell, a four-year corrections officer at the Central New Mexico Correctional Facility in Los Lunas, puts it: “How are you supposed to watch over these (inmates) if you can’t stay awake?”
Good question. And one for which state officials, both elected and appointed, need to find an answer – before a tense situation blows up.
This summer, five of the six state-run prisons had vacancy rates of 20 percent or higher. Western New Mexico Correctional Facility in Grants and the Springer Correctional Center both had vacancy rates of more than 40 percent. That is a safety concern for both officers and inmates.
In addition to mandatory overtime, the pay isn’t that great. In 2012 the average corrections officer salary in New Mexico was $31,940, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Nationally, in 2011 corrections officers earned an average annual salary of $43,550.
Private prison contracts with the state stipulate staffing levels. If those prisons fail to comply, Corrections can – and has – slapped them with hefty fines. Corrections Department spokeswoman Alex Tomlin says all of the private prisons, except one, are being fined because of low staffing levels there, too.
Corrections has contracted a study on how to best deploy its sworn officers. It should be done before the 2016 legislative session that begins in mid-January. The primary task of the 30-day session is coming up with a new budget. So more money for raises is a top priority for the Corrections Department. And it should be a priority for legislators and Gov. Susana Martinez, who has been an advocate for targeted raises for essential and hard-to-staff departments – like Corrections.
This is a dangerous situation that must be fixed. There are roughly 7,300 inmates in New Mexico prisons, many for violent crimes. And someone has to watch them.
This editorial first appeared in the Albuquerque Journal. It was written by members of the editorial board and is unsigned as it represents the opinion of the newspaper rather than the writers.
